items.title: 'module' object has no attribute '_CallList'
items.body:
## Issue Type

- [X] Bug Report

## Versions & Configuration

- sure==1.2.9
- CPython 2.7.16
- Linux Ubuntu 19.04

## Steps to reproduce:

Running this:
```py
import pytest
import sure

class deepobj(object):
    def __init__(self, a, b):
        self.a = a
        self.b = b

def test_deepobj():
    d1 = deepobj(42, 53)
    d2 = deepobj(42, 53)
    d1.should.equal(d2)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    pytest.main(['-s', __file__])

```
Fails:
```
(grytest) alexv@pop-os:/opt/Projects/gryphon_check$ python surecheck.py 
=========================================================================================================================== test session starts ============================================================================================================================
platform linux2 -- Python 2.7.16, pytest-4.6.4, py-1.8.0, pluggy-0.12.0
rootdir: /opt/Projects/gryphon_check
collected 1 item                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           

surecheck.py .f.

================================================================================================================================= FAILURES =================================================================================================================================
_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ test_deepobj _______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

    def test_deepobj():
        d1 = deepobj(42, 53)
        d2 = deepobj(42, 53)
>       d1.should.equal(d2)

surecheck.py:14: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
/home/alexv/.virtualenvs/grytest/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sure/__init__.py:377: in wrapper
    value = func(self, *args, **kw)
/home/alexv/.virtualenvs/grytest/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sure/__init__.py:600: in equal
    comparison = DeepComparison(self.obj, what, epsilon).compare()
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 

self = <sure.core.DeepComparison object at 0x7fcd59d08110>

    def compare(self):
        X, Y = self.operands
    
>       if isinstance(X, mock._CallList):
E       AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute '_CallList'

/home/alexv/.virtualenvs/grytest/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sure/core.py:241: AttributeError
```

Just to show it is likely not related with pytest, the same happens when I try to run it with nose2 : 
```
(grytest) alexv@pop-os:/opt/Projects/gryphon_check$ nose2 surecheck
E
======================================================================
ERROR: surecheck.FunctionTestCase (test_deepobj)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/Projects/gryphon_check/surecheck.py", line 14, in test_deepobj
    d1.should.equal(d2)
  File "/home/alexv/.virtualenvs/grytest/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sure/__init__.py", line 377, in wrapper
    value = func(self, *args, **kw)
  File "/home/alexv/.virtualenvs/grytest/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sure/__init__.py", line 600, in equal
    comparison = DeepComparison(self.obj, what, epsilon).compare()
  File "/home/alexv/.virtualenvs/grytest/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sure/core.py", line 241, in compare
    if isinstance(X, mock._CallList):
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute '_CallList'

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.000s

FAILED (errors=1)

```

Any hint on what is going on here ?
Thank you.

items.title: DeprecationWarning: Using or importing the ABCs from 'collections' instead of from  'collections.abc' is deprecated, and in 3.8 it will stop working
items.body:
## Issue Type

Please specify the type of the issue you want to submit:

- [X] Bug Report

## Versions & Configuration

- version of `sure`: **1.4.11**
- implementation and version of python **3.7.2**
- operating system **CentOS Linux release 7.6.1810 (Core)**

## Steps to reproduce (Expected and Actual Results)

Running `pytest`, I get the following warning:

```
/home/user/.virtualenvs/BTTS37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/sure/old.py:26       
  /home/user/.virtualenvs/BTTS37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/sure/old.py:26: DeprecationWarning: Using or importing the ABCs from 'collections' instead of from 
'collections.abc' is deprecated, and in 3.8 it will stop working                
    from collections import Iterable                                            
```

items.title: dicts cannot be checked with equal if key doesn't support <
items.body:
## Issue Type

Please specify the type of the issue you want to submit:

- [X] Bug Report
- [ ] Feature Request
- [ ] Documentation Report
- [ ] General Enhancement Idea
- [ ] ...

## Versions & Configuration

Please specify the following things:

- version of `sure`: 1.4.11
- implementation and version of python: `Python 3.6.5 (default, Mar 30 2018, 06:41:53) [GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 9.0.0 (clang-900.0.39.2)] on darwin`
- operating system: MacOS 10.13.5

## Steps to reproduce (Expected and Actual Results)

```python
import sure
from enum import Enum

class SomeEnum(Enum):
    A = 'A'
    B = 'B'

{SomeEnum.A: 0, SomeEnum.B: 1}.should.equal({SomeEnum.A: 0, SomeEnum.B: 1})
```

Results in: `TypeError: '<' not supported between instances of 'SomeEnum' and 'SomeEnum'`

This should return `True`, and it does if the `dict` only has one item.

items.title: ReadTheDocs website root url redirects to the wrong destination
items.body:
## Issue Type

Please specify the type of the issue you want to submit:

- [x ] Bug Report
- [ ] Feature Request
- [ ] Documentation Report
- [ ] General Enhancement Idea
- [ ] ...

## Versions & Configuration
N/A

## Steps to reproduce (Expected and Actual Results)

If you visit http://sure.readthedocs.io/ then you get redirected to http://sure.readthedocs.io/en/master/ and get a 'Permission denied' error page, while the documentation is available at http://sure.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ .

items.title: Six usage in setup.py prevents install in virtualenv
items.body:
Last (1.4.10) release breaks python 2.7 virtualenv (15.1.0) installs.

```bash
virtualenv env
./env/bin/pip install sure
Collecting sure
  Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/b4/63/20dcfbb9ce5e8de5e9377bebee4a80ac0ec431e827d917d5494f58c8ba3f/sure-1.4.10.tar.gz (46kB)
    100% |████████████████████████████████| 51kB 4.6MB/s 
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
      File "/tmp/pip-install-J5aA4I/sure/setup.py", line 79, in <module>
        version=read_version(),
      File "/tmp/pip-install-J5aA4I/sure/setup.py", line 48, in read_version
        exec(file_data, context)
      File "<string>", line 30, in <module>
    ImportError: No module named six
    ----------------------------------------
Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pip-install-J5aA4I/sure/
```

For the time being, must lock version to 1.4.9

items.title: Tests fail on Python 3.7
items.body:
## Issue Type

- [x] Bug Report

## Versions & Configuration

- version of `sure` is `master`
- implementation and version of python: CPython 3.7
- operating system: all (but Linux mostly)

## Steps to reproduce (Expected and Actual Results)

See Travis CI results. https://travis-ci.org/gabrielfalcao/sure/jobs/372528183

 * Expected result: tests pass on 3.7
 * Actual result: tests fail on 3.7

## What's going on

I'm trying to bootstrap everything in Fedora on Python 3.7 in order to update to 3.7 in Fedora 29.
The `python-sure` RPM package (that's this `sure`) fails to build because of test failures (other packages are blocked by this). I see you've enabled 3.7 on Travis CI, yet you allow it to fail.

Most notably this is the problem:

```python
AttributeError: module 're' has no attribute '_pattern_type'
```

I'll try to stitch a fix.

BTW See you on [PyCon CZ](https://cz.pycon.org/2018/)  :czech_republic: :snake:  @gabrielfalcao

items.title: traceback on "(1.).should.equal(5.,2.)"
items.body:
Bug Report (maybe...)

sure 1.4.6 + python 3.6.2 on Arch-Linux

```
import sure
(1.).should.equal(5.,4.) # ok, the result is True
(1.).should.equal(5.,3.) # traceback printout with:     IndexError: tuple index out of range
```

items.title: UnicodeDecodeError comparing bytes
items.body:
## Issue Type

Please specify the type of the issue you want to submit:

- [x] Bug Report

## Versions & Configuration

Please specify the following things:

- version of `sure`: 1.4.5
- implementation and version of python:
```
Python 2.7.13 (default, Mar 17 2017, 16:37:30)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 8.0.0 (clang-800.0.42.1)] on darwin
```
- operating system: osx 10.11.6

## Steps to reproduce (Expected and Actual Results)

Please specify the steps to reproduce your issue including the expected and the actual results.

```
% cat test_sure_bytes.py
import base64

from unittest import TestCase
import sure  # noqa


class TestBytesCompare(TestCase):

    def setUp(self):
        data_b64 = (
            'MIGHAgEAMBMGByqGSM49AgEGCCqGSM49AwEHBG0wawIBAQQg11zwkcKSsSppm8Du13'
            'je6lmwR7hEVeKMw5L8NQEN/CehRANCAAT9RzcGN/S9yN7mWP+xfLGEuw/TyHRBiW4c'
            'GE6AczRgske/P8eq8trs8unSJPCp0YPKrmCEcuotL/8BHQ4Y1AVK'
        )
        self.data = base64.b64decode(data_b64)

    def tearDown(self):
        pass

    def test_bytes_compare(self):
        self.data.should.equal(self.data)

% nosetests test_sure_bytes.py
E
======================================================================
ERROR: test_bytes_compare (test_sure_bytes.TestBytesCompare)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/private/tmp/sure-test/test_sure_bytes.py", line 22, in test_bytes_compare
    self.data.should.equal(self.data)
  File "/Users/cdunham/.pyenv/versions/2.7.13/envs/sure-test-2.7.13/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sure/__init__.py", line 384, in wrapper
    value = func(self, *args, **kw)
  File "/Users/cdunham/.pyenv/versions/2.7.13/envs/sure-test-2.7.13/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sure/__init__.py", line 650, in equal
    comparison = DeepComparison(self.obj, what, epsilon).compare()
  File "/Users/cdunham/.pyenv/versions/2.7.13/envs/sure-test-2.7.13/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sure/core.py", line 238, in compare
    safe_X, safe_Y = safe_format_repr(X), safe_format_repr(Y)
  File "/Users/cdunham/.pyenv/versions/2.7.13/envs/sure-test-2.7.13/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sure/core.py", line 232, in safe_format_repr
    safe_repr = string.replace('{', '{{').replace('}', '}}')
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0x81 in position 1: ordinal not in range(128)

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.002s

FAILED (errors=1)
```

items.title: matcher cannot handle strings containing %
items.body:
## Issue Type
- [X] Bug Report

## Versions & Configuration

sure version 1.4.1; cpython (3.6); ubuntu (14.04) (also asynctest 0.10.0)

## Steps to reproduce (Expected and Actual Results)

Given a simple string match with a '%' on the left hand side:
`'hello%world'.should.be.equal('hello%other')`

(note: answers do not match, this issue only manifests on test failure)
(also note: a similar problem happens if the '%' is only on the right hand side)

One might expect a failure message e.g. `X is 'hello%world' whereas Y is 'hello%other'`

However, this instead results in an error (full stack trace at the bottom of this ticket):
> File "{my home dir}/.pyenv/versions/3.6.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sure/core.py", line 89, in compare_generic
>    m = msg_format % (red(c.current_X_keys), green(c.current_Y_keys))
ValueError: unsupported format character 'w' (0x77) at index 14

Since I encountered this comparing url quoted strings, a workaround for my specific case is to apply `urllib.parse.unquote` to both sides of the comparison, but this seems problematic in the general case of percents in strings - and is initially confusing regardless - so I thought I should open it as an issue. 

#### full stack trace

> File "/home/{homedir}/.pyenv/versions/3.6.0/lib/python3.6/unittest/case.py", line 59, in testPartExecutor
>   yield
> File "/home/{homedir}/.pyenv/versions/3.6.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/asynctest/case.py", line 276, in run
>   self._run_test_method(testMethod)
> File "/home/{homedir}/.pyenv/versions/3.6.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/asynctest/case.py", line 328, in _run_test_method
>   self.loop.run_until_complete(result)
> File "/home/{homedir}/.pyenv/versions/3.6.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/asynctest/case.py", line 202, in wrapper
>   return method(*args, **kwargs)
> File "/home/{homedir}/.pyenv/versions/3.6.0/lib/python3.6/asyncio/base_events.py", line 466, in run_until_complete
>   return future.result()
> File "/home/{homedir}/workspace/nimbus-invoke/invoke/test/test_droplet.py", line 383, in test_sends_logstream_url
>   'hello%world'.should.be.equal('hello%other')
> File "/home/{homedir}/.pyenv/versions/3.6.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sure/__init__.py", line 384, in wrapper
>   value = func(self, *args, **kw)
> File "/home/{homedir}/.pyenv/versions/3.6.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sure/__init__.py", line 650, in equal
>   comparison = DeepComparison(self.obj, what, epsilon).compare()
> File "/home/{homedir}/.pyenv/versions/3.6.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sure/core.py", line 230, in compare
>   exp = self.compare_generic(X, Y, **kwargs)
> File "/home/{homedir}/.pyenv/versions/3.6.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/sure/core.py", line 89, in compare_generic
>   m = msg_format % (red(c.current_X_keys), green(c.current_Y_keys))

items.title: sure flake8 issue
items.body:
## Question

Hello, comrades! Thanks for this really cool library!

Flake8 shows me `F401 module imported but unused` error for `import sure`. PyCharm also show `sure` as unused.
Can i bypass this issue? I wan to use git pre-commit hook for flake8 checks without ignoring F401. Sorry for my english :)

items.title: context manager to enforce certain assertion error
items.body:
_This feature was taken from the former TODO.md originally written by @gabrielfalcao_:

> ## create a context manager that enforces a certain assertion error
> 
> ``` python
> # ...
> 
> name = myapi.do_something_that_returns_string()
> 
> with sure.ensure('the return value actually looks like: {0}', name):
>    name.should.contain('whatever')
> ```
> 
> the `ensure` context manager should identify whether the raised
> exception as an assertion error and if so, replace the assertion error
> witha custom message passed to the ensure context manager.

items.title: conflict with asynctest project

milestone.description: Release bug fix version which fixes currently known bugs in GitHub's issue tracker.

items.body:
## Issue Type

It is Bug Report about conflict Sure lib and asynctest (https://github.com/Martiusweb/asynctest).
## Versions & Configuration

Using: 
sure=1.3.0
asynctest==0.7.1
Docker Python 3.5.1 (https://hub.docker.com/_/python/)
## Steps to reproduce

I'm trying to use sure and asynctest in one test:

``` python
import asynctest
# I don't ever use it but import actually is enough
import sure

class Test_Story(asynctest.TestCase):
    @asynctest.mock.patch('story.async_function')
    async def test_async_story(self, mock):
        pass

```

and it fails with error:

```
   Traceback (most recent call last):
    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/asynctest/case.py line 261 in run
      self._run_test_method(testMethod)
    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/asynctest/case.py line 313 in _run_test_method
      self.loop.run_until_complete(result)
    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/asynctest/case.py line 196 in wrapper
      return method(*args, **kwargs)
    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/asyncio/base_events.py line 337 in run_until_complete
      return future.result()
    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/asyncio/futures.py line 274 in result
      raise self._exception
    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/asyncio/tasks.py line 239 in _step
      result = coro.send(None)

    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/asynctest/mock.py line 429 in patched_generator
      return (yield from patched(*args, **kwargs))
    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/asynctest/mock.py line 395 in patched
      arg = patching.__enter__()
    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/unittest/mock.py line 1271 in __enter__
      new = Klass(**_kwargs)
    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/asynctest/mock.py line 274 in __init__
      super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/unittest/mock.py line 902 in __init__
      _spec_state, _new_name, _new_parent, **kwargs
    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/unittest/mock.py line 397 in __init__
      self._mock_add_spec(spec, spec_set, _spec_as_instance, _eat_self)
    /usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/asynctest/mock.py line 78 in _mock_add_spec
      if asyncio.iscoroutinefunction(getattr(spec, attr)):
   AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '_spec_coroutines'
```

and if I will remove `import sure` we won't get error.
After little bit investigation I've found that maybe problem that `Sure` mock somehow `__dict__`. And seems is related to this caveat https://github.com/gabrielfalcao/sure/blob/master/docs/source/api-reference.rst#holy-guacamole-how-did-you-implement-that-feature-

PS:
related issue in asynctest project https://github.com/Martiusweb/asynctest/issues/18

items.title: Merge sphinx documentation and move to RTD
items.body:
We should merge the sphinx documentation branch as soon as possible.
And I think it'd be a good chance to move the main documentation to rtd as well (the current doc server seems to be down)

I've seen that there is a rtd doc online already, but not up-to-date: https://sure.readthedocs.io

@gabrielfalcao what was your plan?

items.title: Move items from TODO.md into GitHub issue
items.body: Move all items from the TODO.md into the GitHub issue tracker to have a better overview of the open issues and to keep track and easily discuss about them

items.title: expect.to.contain returns True always
items.body:
Steps to repro:

```
>>> from sure import expect
>>> expect("hello").to.contain("world")
True
```

Looks like [this](https://github.com/gabrielfalcao/sure/blob/master/sure/__init__.py#L874) may be overwriting `actual` and `expected`, so the comparison is always true.

items.title: is there a .skip() available?
items.body: as an in-between passing green and failing red ?

items.title: What about python 2.6 support?
items.body:
Is `sure` supposed to support python 2.6 for new releases?
Does anyone rely on python 2.6 support?

Today, python 2.6 is not tested but in the code base are still hacks to support python 2.6 which, in case we do not support 2.6 any longer, could be removed.

items.title: Update github description
items.body:
Github description is wrong. visionmedia moved shouldjs to the tj user and then to an own organization:
https://github.com/shouldjs/should.js

Link in README.md is fixed with #96

items.title: Future of this project
items.body:
This is mainly a question for @gabrielfalcao 
Where do you see this project going? There are a lot of issues and some pull requests which need some work. I really appreciate this package and I'm using it in several private projects and at work - as probably others too. Some of the issues and pull request are very appreciable for the projects I am using sure.
If you do not have time to maintain this project any more: I'm sure there are people here who would help (including me).

:beers:

items.title: AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute '_CallList'
items.body:
Hi,
When I run my tests I get the same error for all tests:

```
  File "/home/vagrant/.tox/project/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/sure/__init__.py", line 377, in wrapper
    value = func(self, *args, **kw)
  File "/home/vagrant/.tox/project/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/sure/__init__.py", line 600, in equal
    comparison = DeepComparison(self.obj, what, epsilon).compare()
  File "/home/vagrant/.tox/project/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/sure/core.py", line 241, in compare
    if isinstance(X, mock._CallList):
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute '_CallList'
```

This is strange because the same test worked, and I dont know what I did to them breaking.
How can I fix this?

items.title: Can test-requirements be unpinned please?
items.body: Can test-requirements be unpinned? e.g. use >=, rather than ==? There is a newer release of sure at least.

items.title: importing sure breaks py.test junit-xml output

milestone.description: Milestone with new features and bugfixes

items.body:
# Working case

```
def test_demo():
    assert True
```

`py.test test_demo.py --junit-xml=junit.xml`

junit.xml looks like: 

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<testsuite errors="0" failures="0" name="pytest" skips="0" tests="1" time="0.007">
  <testcase classname="test.test_demo" name="test_demo" time="0.000320196151733"/>
</testsuite>
```
# Failing case

Just add an import sure: 

```
import sure
def test_demo():
    assert True
```

`py.test test_demo.py --junit-xml=junit.xml`

Now junit.xml is empty: 

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<testsuite errors="0" failures="0" name="pytest" skips="0" tests="0" time="0.021">
</testsuite>
```

items.title: 1.2.8 have a failed test w/Python 3.4.2
items.body:
Full log:

```
............................E...............................................................................................
======================================================================
ERROR: test_assertion_builder.test_throw_matching_regex
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/build/python-sure/src/sure-1.2.8/sure/old.py", line 125, in raises
    self._src(*self._callable_args, **self._callable_kw)
  File "/build/python-sure/src/sure-1.2.8/tests/test_assertion_builder.py", line 639, in blah
    raise ValueError(msg)
ValueError: this message

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/nose/case.py", line 198, in runTest
    self.test(*self.arg)
```

items.title: `should.throw` to take a regular expression to match the message
items.body:
There are edge cases where the same exception can throw different messages in different operating systems, for example.

It would be really helpful if sure could optionally take a regular expression as an argument.

items.title: equality of floats with epsilon
items.body:
There is no proper way to check floats for equality.
Can we add a new `compare_float` method in `DeepComparison` to check for float equality with an epsilon?

:beers:

items.title: Fix tests on pypy (+enable testing on travis-ci)
sure is not installable in Python 3.4.0
items.body:
trying to `pip install sure` `ez_install sure` or even `python setup.py install` does not work in python 3.4.0
why? 
well if you ask me you got a little too clever for your own good.

the read_version() function in the setup.py file fails

```
Running setup.py (path:/tmp/pip_build_ubuntu/sure/setup.py) egg_info for package sure
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 17, in <module>
      File "/tmp/pip_build_ubuntu/sure/setup.py", line 53, in <module>
        version=read_version(),
      File "/tmp/pip_build_ubuntu/sure/setup.py", line 40, in read_version
        finder.visit(ast.parse(local_file('sure', '__init__.py')))
      File "/tmp/pip_build_ubuntu/sure/setup.py", line 45, in <lambda>
        open(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), *f)).read()
      File "/usr/lib/python3.4/encodings/ascii.py", line 26, in decode
        return codecs.ascii_decode(input, self.errors)[0]
    UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 143: ordinal not in range(128)
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "<string>", line 17, in <module>

  File "/tmp/pip_build_ubuntu/sure/setup.py", line 53, in <module>

    version=read_version(),

  File "/tmp/pip_build_ubuntu/sure/setup.py", line 40, in read_version

    finder.visit(ast.parse(local_file('sure', '__init__.py')))

  File "/tmp/pip_build_ubuntu/sure/setup.py", line 45, in <lambda>

    open(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), *f)).read()

  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/encodings/ascii.py", line 26, in decode

    return codecs.ascii_decode(input, self.errors)[0]

UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 143: ordinal not in range(128)
```

I've gotten around this for now by editing the setup.py file localy and hardcoding the version.

items.title: Add tests to source package
items.body: The tarball which is up on PyPI doesn't contain test cases, so it might be a very good idea to include them. Especially useful if distributions want to pick up `sure`.

items.title: PyPi package has frozen and incorrectly labelled dependencies
items.body:
The pypi package has install dependencies on: 
nose==1.3.0
rednose==0.4.1

Firstly these are not install dependencies they are test dependencies (and rednose probably is neither and belongs in development.txt because it is only referenced by Makefile) 

Secondly, because this is imported directly into setup.py this means that the library is being published with a strict requirement on these versions. This is a similar problem to what we had in HTTPretty so i'm providing the following links which i hope will explain the difference between requirements.txt and setup.py and why it's bad to publish strict version requirements in a setup.py file:
- http://blog.miguelgrinberg.com/post/the-package-dependency-blues (get's a little lengthy with the whole story).
- https://caremad.io/blog/setup-vs-requirement/

Thanks for your help.

items.title: Implement OrderedDict comparison
Asserting that callable does not return given value silently fails
items.body:
The following should raise an error, but doesn't:

```
import sure
def f():
    return 0

f.when.called_with().should_not.return_value(0)
```

It looks like should_not does not negate when used with called_with()

Use of called_with() and return_value() is documented at http://falcao.it/sure/reference.html#function-when-called_with-arg1--kwarg1-2--should-return_value-value-  so I assume negating it with should_not should also work.

items.title: source.should.look_the_same_as(destination) diff
items.body: I'm currently testing XML comparison, diffs would have been nice [`difflib.Differ`](http://docs.python.org/2/library/difflib.html#differ-example)

items.title: Borrowing CPython object extension code
items.body:
Hi!

I'm the maintainer of the [pyshould](https://github.com/drslump/pyshould) library and it would be great to borrow your code from `magic.py` in order to support the `x.should` syntax in my library. It's a very interesting hack!

Since _sure_ is licensed as GPL3 but _pyshould_ is under MIT I would need your written consent before integrating that code if you agree to it. I guess it will suffice to simply reply to this issue stating that you allow such inclusion in _pyshould_.

PS: I would fully understand if you prefer to keep your code only under its current license.

items.title: .called_with() doesn't pass correct arguments through
items.body:
It looks like `called_with()` is broken in the newest version (1.2.5)

Failing test:

``` python
import sure

def raise_err(foobar):
    raise ValueError()

def test():
    raise_err.when.called_with("adsf").should.throw(ValueError)
```

Traceback

``` traceback
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "nose/case.py", line 197, in runTest
    self.test(*self.arg)
  File "test.py", line 10, in test
    raise_err.when.called_with("adsf").should.throw(ValueError)
  File "sure/__init__.py", line 375, in wrapper
    value = func(self, *args, **kw)
  File "sure/__init__.py", line 789, in throw
    return _that.raises(*args, **kw)
  File "sure/old.py", line 129, in raises
    self._src, exc, e.__class__, traceback.format_exc(e)))
AssertionError: <function raise_err at 0x1036ec140> should raise <type 'exceptions.ValueError'>, but raised <type 'exceptions.TypeError'>:
ORIGINAL EXCEPTION:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "sure/old.py", line 117, in raises
    self._src(*self._callable_args, **self._callable_kw)
TypeError: raise_err() takes exactly 1 argument (0 given)
```

I think it may have to do with this commit, but am not positive yet: https://github.com/gabrielfalcao/sure/commit/e292cd593b40620a043755ea732f50c3d9fe4d24

items.title: Py.test runs each test thrice with sure version >= 1.2.2
items.body:
### Steps to repro

```
$ mkvirtualenv trial
$ pip install py.test==2.5.1 py==1.4.19 sure==1.2.2
```

create a test_trial.py file with a simple unit test in current directory, there should be an `import sure` in the file

```
$ py.test
```
### Actual output

```
============================= test session starts ==============================
platform linux -- Python 3.3.3 -- pytest-2.5.1
collected 1 items

test_trial.py .

=========================== 3 passed in 0.07 seconds ===========================
```
### Expected output

```
============================= test session starts ==============================
platform linux -- Python 3.3.3 -- pytest-2.5.1
collected 1 items

test_trial.py ...

=========================== 1 passed in 0.10 seconds ===========================
```

items.title: .equal() should convert `mock._CallList` instances to lists
items.body:
Otherwise, the user has to do that all the time to avoid the following error:

![screen shot 2013-10-25 at 9 25 25 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1459190/1412657/ddbcdda0-3ddd-11e3-8023-0738314d753d.png)

Here's a basic test case

``` python
import mock

def test_equals_handles_mock_call_list():
    ".equal() Should convert mock._CallList instances to lists"

    # Given the following mocked callback
    callback = mock.Mock()

    # When I call the callback with a few parameters twice
    callback(a=1, b=2)
    callback(a=3, b=4)

    # Then I see I can compare the call list without manually
    # converting anything
    callback.call_args_list.should.equal([
        mock.call(a=1, b=2),
        mock.call(a=3, b=4),
    ])
```

items.title: Length inequalities
items.body:
At present, one can only write

``` python
biglist = [1, 2, 3]
biglist.should.have.length_of(3)
```

Whereas it's sometimes useful to have

``` python
biglist = [1, 2, 3]
biglist.should.have.length.greater_or_equal_to(3)
```

items.title: Test for object identity
items.body:
Sometimes I want to test that an object is the _same object_ that I set up, rather than another object that happens to equate to it. This is useful when using mutable values, for example.

At the moment, you have to explicitly use Python's `is` operator, or compare their `id`s:

``` python
>>> import sure
>>> d1 = {'four':4}
>>> d2 = d1
>>> d3 = {'four':4}
>>> (d2 is d1).should.be.true
True
>>> (d3 is d1).should.be.false
True
>>> # or...
... (id(d2)).should.equal(id(d1))
True
>>> (id(d3)).should_not.equal(id(d1))
True
```

I propose overloading `be` for this purpose:

``` python
>>> d2.should.be(d1)
True
>>> d3.should_not.be(d1)
True
```

items.title: Provide a way to extend sure

milestone.description: Release bug fix version which fixes currently known bugs in GitHub's issue tracker.

items.body:
So that the code below is valid:

``` python

from sure import assertion, chain, chainproperty
from lxml import html


@assertion
def attribute(parent, is_negative, name):  # *args, **kw FTW
    if is_negative:
        return name not in parent.object.attrib
    else:
        return name in parent.object.attrib

@chain
def child(parent, name):  # *args, **kw FTW
    items = parent.object.cssselect(name)
    items.should.have.length_of(1)

    return items[0]

@chainproperty
def having(parent):
    return parent.object

def test_anchors_in_1st_level_headers():
    headers = dom.cssselect("h1")

    headers.should.have.length_of()

    h1 = headers[0]

    h1.should.have.attribute("name").being.equal("api-reference")
    h1.should.have.child("a").having.attribute("href").equal("#api-reference")

```

items.title: "should.throw" assertion is true for any Exception type thrown/expected
items.body:
This is an error in old.py (SHA#00a60ab0)

This is the patch I used to fix it:

```
@@ -116,9 +116,9 @@
         except Exception, e:
             if isinstance(exc, basestring):
                 msg = utf8_bytes(exc)
+                exc = type(e)

             err = utf8_bytes(str(e))
-            exc = type(e)

             if isinstance(exc, type) and issubclass(exc, Exception):
                 if not isinstance(e, exc):
```

There what I saw is that the type of `e` (the thrown exception) is assigned to `exc` (the expected exception type. That line makes sense only inside the if block, where `exc` gets the type of `e` because was originally just the exception message string.

```
  File "/private/tmp/sure/sure/__init__.py", line 39, in <module>

  File "/private/tmp/sure/sure/magic.py", line 41, in <module>

  File "/opt/local/lib/pypy/lib_pypy/_ctypes/structure.py", line 137, in struct_setattr
```

items.title: sure.any()
items.body: sometimes I wanna check a value of a key from a dictionary, for example, but the values from the other keys don't really matter. Currently there is no way to do this but copy all the values from the other dict on the assert dict. I propose the following: ``` python a = {'key': 1, 'other_key': 4} b = {'key': 1, 'other_key': sure.any()} assert that(a).equals(b) // True ``` In the context of this code, the value of 'other_key' is completely unnecessary to test, so i create an instance of sure.any to match with it and 'any' is equal to everything. This is not a new concept, some other libraries already implement it, like Jasmine. direct link: [http://pivotal.github.com/jasmine/#section-Matching_Anything_with_jasmine.any](http://pivotal.github.com/jasmine/#section-Matching_Anything_with_jasmine.any

items.title: Allow monkey patching of methods already implemented by sure

milestone.description: Milestone with new features and bugfixes

items.body:
Sure should allow overwritting the `do`, `does` and all the other methods (see below) when using the CPython-compatible syntax sugar (i.e.: `(1).should.be.an(int)`)
- `do`
- `do_not`
- `does`
- `does_not`
- `doesnt`
- `should`
- `should_not`
- `shouldnt`
- `must`

For instance, this test should pass:

``` python
import sure

class Foo(object):
    pass

instance = Foo()
instance.do = "anything"

```

I will be packaging "sure" for Fedora because I want to package lettuce and "sure" is its requirement. I'd like to ask you if it would be possible to add the COPYING file to official pypi releases - it is optimal for packaging, if the licensing is contained in the upstream source.

Thank you.

items.title: .raises always passes
items.body: Using .raises doesn't seem to work - I can't break the test

items.title: that(something).is_greater_than(x) etc
items.body:
Just taking the module in for the first time. I really like the readability and clarity of the tests. 

But on my first use, I tried doing some comparison operations. There appears to be a len_greater_than, len_greater_than_or_equals, etc, but the simple comparisons (which I assume would be named is_greater_than, is_greater_than_or_equals, is_less_than, doesnt_equal, and so on) are absent. 

Are they really missing, or am I misunderstanding how to express those tests? I was able to add them with the @that.is_a_matcher decorator, but they seem like core tests that should be available to all. 

The code for these is of course very simple. I would, however, be happy to submit a patch if you like.

items.title: timed tests may take  optional parameters utcnow and now
items.body:
It can be useful within some kinds of tests

```
from sure import *

@within(five=microseconds):
def test_foobar(utcnow, now):
    # ... http request test
    assert http.headers['date'] == utcnow.strftime('%a, %d %b %Y %H:%M:%S GMT')
```

items.title: optional "context" parameter on contextual setup/teardown
